I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) supported the decentralization of water resources 
management in Indonesia from December 2007 to June 2010 through a technical assistance 
(TA) for Capacity Building in Water Resources in a Decentralized Environment,1 which aimed to 
(i) strengthen the capacity for integrated water resources management (IWRM), (ii) implement 
the Water Law of 2004, (iii) follow up recommendations from the Capacity Building Project in the 
Water  Resources  Sector, 2  and  (iv)  build  the  capacity  of  local  government  under  the 
decentralization policy. The TA for Capacity Building in Water Resources in a Decentralized 
Environment produced a draft National Strategy for Capacity Building in Water Resources 
Management under the Water Law and 29 capacity development action plans (CDAPs) in seven 
provinces.3 However, significant further efforts are needed to realize the endorsement of the 
national  capacity  development  strategy  by  the  government.  In  addition,  capacity  of 
decentralized water resources agencies (WRAs) needs strengthening to implement the Water 
Law and the approved 29 CDAPs.   
 
2.  In September 2010, the Government of Indonesia requested ADB to provide further 
support for CDAP implementation in pilot river basins, including the approval of the national 
strategy for capacity building in decentralized WRAs. ADB considered the proposed capacity 
development TA a high priority and fielded a fact-finding mission from 21 to 24 September 2010. 
The mission and the government concurred with the impact, outcome, outputs, implementation 
arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference for consultants. The design 
and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The government promulgated the Water Law in 2004 for sustainable management of 
water resources, but its enforcement has been hampered by gaps in human resources capacity 
in terms of the number and skill mix of staff.5 The problems are mainly the result of (i) a decade-
long zero-growth policy for civil servants’ recruitment resulting in the shortage of well trained 
water sector professionals; (ii) insufficient knowledge of WRAs on how to plan and implement 
IWRM; and (iii) the decentralization of public administrative responsibilities including budget and 
staff allocation. The effective implementation of the Water Law and sector plans needs human 
resources capacity building. 
 
4.  The Directorate General of Water Resources (DGWR) within the Ministry of Public 
Works  is  responsible  for  overall  water  sector  policy  guidance  in  the  country.  It  is  also 
responsible for implementing IWRM in national river basins. DGWR prepared the necessary 
government regulations, reorganized its structure to implement the Water Law, and identified 
the human resource capacity gaps for its implementation. In 2008, the government approved 
the regulation on water resources management6 following the Water Law, which defines and 
describes the roles of the WRAs.

5.  Under the Water Law, independent WRAs providing water related services in provincial 
governments  were  established  within  decentralized  local  government  administrations.  The 
decentralization provides the water sector with opportunities for local WRAs to assume their 
new role in effective water resources management. The decentralized WRAs, however, are still 
learning and understanding their roles under the Water Law. Specifically decentralized WRAs 
lack clarity on (i) the scope of their jurisdiction; (ii) the roles and responsibilities of national, 
provincial, and district WRAs; and (iii) budget allocation. Clear demarcated responsibility with 
commensurate resources, adequate incentives, and accountability for each agency within a 
clearly managed decentralized environment, are required to implement the Water Law. 
 
6.  In  response  to  these needs,  ADB provided  the  TA for  Capacity  Building  in Water 
Resources in a Decentralized Environment. It assisted DGWR and the seven provinces in 
preparing CDAPs, which included performing a diagnostic analysis of each WRA, familiarizing 
the agencies with the CDAPs, establishing a change management team, training trainers, and 
collecting information and data. The CDAPs helped the government define its capacity building 
strategy,  including  detailed  implementation  arrangements  and  required  funding.  The  main 
elements of a CDAP were (i) the policy framework; (ii) institutional development; (iii) human 
resource management; (iv) financial management, budgeting, and planning; (v) monitoring and 
evaluation;  and  (vi)  human  resources  development,  education,  and  training.  The  CDAPs 
reflected the new institutional roles and identified the new organizational needs of the local 
WRAs under the Water Law.  
 
7.  The  CDAPs,  however,  have  not  been  implemented  as  the  WRAs  have  not  fully 
appreciated  the  importance  of  the  changes  in  their  roles  and  responsibilities  in  the 
implementation of the Water Law. In addition, DGWR was unable to provide WRAs with a 
budget for CDAP implementation. However, of the seven provinces, only Aceh and North 
Sulawesi demonstrated their commitment to CDAPs.  
 
8.  In 2010, based on the 29 CDAPs in the seven provinces, DGWR prepared a draft 
strategy for national capacity building of WRAs with assistance from the TA for Capacity Building 
in Water Resources in a Decentralized Environment. The strategy, however, has not yet been 
endorsed by the government as further consultations and greater buy-in from stakeholders are 
needed.  
 
9.  In  addition  to  effective  CDAP  implementation,  the  regulation  on  water  resources 
management requires that (i) the local governments should establish a river basin council in 
each river basin and (ii) all river basins have a strategic river basin framework (pola) and its 
implementation plan (rencana) by 2011. Civil society engagement and IWRM principles are 
embedded in the regulation. This target is challenging because of the limited capacity of local 
WRAs. For example, Aceh has 11 river basins and is one of two champions in river basin 
management among the seven provinces. However, it could establish only one river basin 
council in the Aceh Besar river basin and prepare a pola without a rencana.  
 
10.  A  number  of  development  partners  are  providing  complementary  and  coordinated 
support for the implementation of the Water Law and capacity development of WRAs. In 2011, 
DGWR prepared a human resources development master plan for itself and national WRA staff 
with  assistance  from  the  United  Nations  Educational,  Scientific  and  Cultural  Organization 
(UNESCO). DGWR has recruited 40 staff in 2009 and 20 staff in 2010. The World Bank will also 
assist with the capacity development of national and local WRAs through the planned second 
phase of the Water and Irrigation Sector Management Program, which will assist 12 provinces 
in implementing their CDAPs, including the five provinces covered by the TA for Capacity

3 
Building  in  Water  Resources  in  a  Decentralized  Environment.7 In  addition,  ADB’s  TA  for 
Institutional  Strengthening  for  the  Water  Resources  Sector  will  assist  the  government  in 
preparing  a  stronger  institutional  framework  for  the  water  resources  sector.8 The  TA  will 
complement the World Bank support for implementing the CDAPs in other provinces. 
 
11.  To ensure the champion provinces continue to support sustainable decentralized water 
resources management, DGWR needs to communicate the strategy to relevant stakeholders to 
effect  its  implementation.  This  will  also  help  the  government  to  obtain  the  necessary 
endorsement of the strategy. Furthermore, the decentralized WRAs need to establish river basin 
councils, develop a pola and a rencana for each pilot river basin (as top priority activities of the 
CDAPs),  and  strengthen  their  water  resources  management  technologies  and  reporting 
systems.    
 
12.  The TA supports Indonesia’s priorities outlined in the Medium-Term Development Plan 
for 2011–2015 and is consistent with the ADB Water Policy,9 the Indonesia Country Partnership 
Strategy, 2006–2009,10 and the proposed new Indonesia Country Partnership Strategy, 2011-
2013 (scheduled for approval in 2011).  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The impact of the TA will be improved water resources management in Indonesia. The 
outcome  will  be  improved  capacity  of  decentralized  WRAs  for  effective  Water  Law 
implementation.  
 
14.  The outputs of the TA will include: (i) pilot implementation of CDAPs for pilot river basins in 
Aceh and North Sulawesi,11 (ii) a national strategy endorsed for capacity building on water 
resources management, (iii) increased capacity of six pilot river basin councils in the Aceh and 
North Sulawesi provinces, and (iv) participatory polas and rencanas prepared for pilot river 
basins. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
15.  The TA will implement CDAP activities in the pilot river basins of the Aceh and North 
Sulawesi provinces. The CDAP activities will be implemented based on implementation plans 
prepared by the river basin councils using a participatory approach. There is a risk of delayed 
counterpart  budget  allocation  for  implementing  the  CDAPs,  however,  central  and  local 
governments have made assurances that their contributions of counterpart staff and budget will 
be provided on time.  
 
16.  The TA will also review the CDAPs of the seven provinces in order for DGWR to update 
and endorse the national strategy for capacity development. DGWR will consult with the seven

17.  As all the WRAs have different statuses on river basin council, pola, rencana, and water 
resources management activities, the TA will help DGWR provide guidance to the pilot river 
basin  organizations.  The  TA  will  also  assist  each  province  in  implementing  its  capacity 
development  activities  according  to  their  priorities.  The  TA  will  support  civil  societies’ 
participation in the river basin councils. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $2.25 million equivalent. Of this, $1.80 million will 
be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by 
ADB. The Government of Indonesia will finance the remaining $0.45 million equivalent as in-
kind contribution for offices, remuneration, and per diem of counterpart staff, workshops, and 
reports. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  The executing agency of the TA is the Ministry of Public Works and the implementing 
agency is DGWR. DGWR will implement the TA activities in close coordination with provincial 
water resources departments. Each provincial water resources department of Aceh and North 
Sulawesi will carry out priority CDAP activities in the three pilot river basins. BAPPENAS will 
facilitate  the  consultation  on  the  draft  national  strategy  and  provide  support  for  strategy 
consultation workshops in Jakarta. Civil society organizations will be invited to participate in the 
TA  activities,  not  only  in  the  consultation  workshops  but  also  in  the  river  basin  council 
management and capacity development activities. 
 
20.  The  CDAP  implementation  in  the  Aceh  province  will  involve  the  provincial  water 
resource department, Aceh Besar river basin organization, Sumatra 1 river basin organization, 
and the Bireun district. The North Sulawesi province will also implement the CDAPs in the 
provincial water resources department, Sulawesi 1 river basin organization, North Sulawesi river 
basin organization, and Minahasa district. The provincial departments will support the river 
basin councils in the pilot river basins. 
 
21.  The TA will require 132 person-months of consulting services over an implementation 
period of 3 years from 1 September 2011 to 31 August 2014. The consultant services include 12 
person-months of one international water resources planning specialist and 120 person-months 
of six national consultants, which include two specialists in Jakarta for 20 person-months each 
and  two  specialists  in  both  Aceh  and  North  Sulawesi  for  20  person-months  each.  The 
consultants will be recruited as individuals. The outline terms of reference is in Appendix 3. All 
consultants will be selected in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  Any  procurement  under  the  TA  will  be  done  in 
accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). All 
procured assets will be transferred to the executing agency at the completion of the TA. All 
disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).

5 
22.  To facilitate the pilot demonstration activities of the CDAPs (Appendix 4), the advance 
payment facility shall be provided to DGWR and the provincial water resources departments in 
Aceh and North Sulawesi. These agencies have sufficient capacity to complete the activity and 
liquidate  the  advances.  The  amount  of  the  advance  shall  be  based  on  the  estimated 
expenditures for up to 6 months. The advances shall be liquidated regularly through submission 
of supporting documents. 
 
23.  The expected outputs and outcome evaluation will be disseminated through workshops 
and training courses during the TA implementation. The TA outputs and outcome evaluation will 
be uploaded in DGWR and ADB websites for public disclosure. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
24.  The  President  recommends  that  the  Board  approve  ADB  administering  technical 
assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,800,000 to the Government of Indonesia to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for Water Resources and 
River Basin Management.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
1.  The technical assistance consultants are envisaged to assist the Directorate General for 
Water Resources (DGWR) in (i) preparing the national strategy for capacity building strategy on 
water resources management, and (ii) implementing capacity development action plans in the 
three pilot river basins each in the Aceh and North Sulawesi provinces. The consultants will also 
train  local  water  resources  agencies  (WRAs)  on  the Water  Law,  the  regulation  on  water 
resources management, and government policy on integrated water resources management. 
 
B.  Scope of Work 
2.  Consultants for 132 person-months will be engaged individually, indicatively including 12 
person-months of one international water resources planning specialist, and 120 person-months 
of six national consultants, which include two specialists in Jakarta for 20 person-months each 
and two specialists for 20 person-months each in both Aceh and North Sulawesi.

3.  Considering the small number and limited capabilities of staff in the local WRAs, the 
consultants need to focus on building capacity in the following major areas.  
 
4.  Institution. Water resources infrastructure has suffered from a lack of institutional support, 
including operational funding. Therefore, the strategy should first be to ensure that the institutional 
and funding bases are adequate before major investments are made in new or improved technology 
systems, including data and information systems. With the support of consultants, DGWR will 
review the organizational needs for river basin planning, river basin leadership (coordination), water 
allocation, water quality management, and flood management. This means the national capacity 
building strategy should perform the role in preparing for investment in institutional strengthening of 
WRAs.  As the institutional arrangements of national WRA, provincial WRA, and district WRA will be 
critical factors in the implementation of the capacity development action plans (CDAPs), the team 
leader will facilitate the institutional arrangements, including the individual staff resources, before 
mobilizing the main resources of the national consultants before the inception workshop. 
 
5.  Staff.  Management  tools  have  been  introduced  in  recent  projects,  but  their  success 
depends  very  much  on  individual  managers’  motivation  to  adopt  them.  If  a  general  active 
management culture is not created at the top of the organization, then management tools such as 
CDAPs and benchmarking will be performed in a mechanical way only. The general management 
environment has to be improved before such tools are applied. The consultants need to introduce

10      Appendix 3 
management tools selectively within programs for coordination, river basin planning, and other water 
resources issues and link them to a performance indicator reporting system for all water agencies, 
adapted as closely as possible to existing financial reporting and budgeting procedures. 
 
6.  Technology.  While water resources management principles are better understood in the 
provinces in Java, local WRAs in other provinces have been found to possess a low level of water 
resources management or services orientation. Two priority programs follow the initiatives of DGWR 
in implementing the Water Law, namely coordination and river basin planning for newly created river 
basin and province coordinating bodies. While a pola (strategic river basin framework) and a 
rencana (implementation plan) must be made for all river basins in Indonesia, the regulation on 
water resources management making them sets out technical and management requirements that 
cannot be fully met at present because of a  lack of data, technical capacity, and water management 
expertise. Lessons from water resources management projects need to be collected for training 
capacity building, in particular integrated flood management and participatory irrigation services. 
 
7.  The integrated flood management program and participatory irrigation services have been 
prioritized and are being conducted in the pilot river basins. While flood control works have been 
designed and, in a few cases, flood warning and prediction information technology have been 
developed, comprehensive flood coordination and management systems have not been set up. The 
institutional and management element is needed in addition to physical works and information 
systems to minimize flood impacts. The strategy for integrated flood management should first be to 
ensure that the institutional and funding base is adequate before major investment is made in new 
or improved technology systems, including data and information system for flood hazard mapping. 
Within river basin planning, river basin leadership, and flood management, it is recommended to 
review the technology needs in the support environment before deciding investments. 
 
8.  Participatory irrigation services also faced problems in the pilot river basins in (i) integrating 
changes into the administrative practice of the provincial and district agencies, and (ii) motivating 
farmers to take on more active roles in irrigation management. Therefore, there are questions about 
how to improve the responsiveness of the administrators to the farmers’ needs. It  may be partly 
addressed by investigating the procedural, funding, and institutional factors to improve the outputs. 
In general, it is necessary to promote better understanding among water users and beneficiaries of 
water services and water management, work towards the application of a service standard system 
for  irrigation,  and  review  policies  and  procedures  to  minimize  impediments  to  water  user 
responsibility. 
 
9.  Training  program. The  consultants  will  prepare a program for the Water  Law and 
management information, which involves an initial stage to develop information and training 
materials  and an  implementation  stage  to  deliver  the  information  and  training.  The  target 
audiences need to be identified and enrolled before the inception workshop. The training will 
provide  (i)  the  general  and detailed provisions  of  the Water Law and  regulations,  (ii)  the 
principles of water resources management, and (iii) how to implement the Water Law. The 
participants will include (i) staff of national WRAs, (ii) staff of provincial and district WRAs, (iii) 
staff of other local government agencies with related roles in water resources, (iv) stakeholders 
in water resources, and (v) the general public. To suit these groups, training materials need to 
be developed for two main audiences: (i) those with core operating responsibilities in the water 
resources sector, and (ii) those with lesser roles in the water resources sector (including the 
public).

C.  Terms of Reference 
10.  Water  resources  planning  specialist  and  team  leader  (international,  12  person-
months). The consultant should have a university degree in civil engineering and at least 20 
years of experience in water resources management projects. The consultant, to be located in 
Jakarta, will (i) act as a team leader of the consultant team, (ii) assess the readiness of 
provinces for integrated water resources management and river basin management using the 
performance indicators of the Network of Asian River Basin Organizations at the inception stage 
in 2011 and the final report stage in 2014, (iii) identify priority reforms required in provincial 
water resource management in the two provinces, (iv) guide a situation and gaps analysis of the 
integrated river basin management in the two provinces, (v) review river basin frameworks and 
implementation plans to identify issues to be addressed by the project, and (vi) assist DGWR 
and BAPPENAS (Badan Perencanaan dan Pembangunan Nasional [State Ministry of National 
Development Planning/National Development Planning Agency]) in finalizing a national strategy 
for capacity building for provincial water resources agencies. The team leader will assist (i) the 
government in developing a water resources capacity building strategy to guide its programs on the 
priorities and approaches to be tackled in the water resources sector; (ii) DGWR, BAPPENAS, and 
the Ministry of Home Affairs in creating a permanent water resources capacity building task force to 
develop, supervise, and review the capacity building strategy and its programs to ensure their 
effectiveness; (iii) DGWR in identifying the need for water resources information and data and 
sustainability factors, and evaluating and monitoring where conditions are found to be favorable for 
long-term sustainability of water data systems (operation capacity and ongoing budget); (iv) the 
capacity development specialist in developing training materials on the Water Law and regulations, 
principles of water resources management, and in implementing the Water Law in provincial and 
district governments; and (v) provincial government in guiding the pilot demonstration activities for 
the pilot river basins in Aceh and North Sulawesi. The team leader will be responsible for compiling 
all the reports and ensuring that the quality of the reports is acceptable to the Asian Development 
Bank and the government. The team leader will submit monthly progress reports to the Asian 
Development Bank and the government. 
 
11.  Institutional  development  specialist/deputy  team  leader  (national,  20  person-
months). The consultant should have a university degree in water resources engineering and at 
least  15  years  of  experience  in  water  resources  management  projects  in  Indonesia.  The 
consultant, located in Jakarta, will be responsible for assisting the team leader in preparing an 
institutional strengthening action plan for integrated river basin management and a national 
strategy for provincial water resources agencies, and assessing the performance indicators of 
river basin organizations by using the Network of Asian River Basin Organizations performance 
indicators at the inception stage in 2011 and the final report stage in 2014. The consultant will 
also monitor the performance of the national consultants, including water resources planners 
and water resources institutional specialists working in the provinces. The consultant should 
introduce management tools and systems to organizations where there is a general management 
program for the whole of the organization, or where the tools are to be introduced as a formal 
requirement. New procedures should be supported and approved by DGWR and by the head of the 
organizations before being implemented within the organizations. Direct dealing with the head of the 
WRA is an essential part of any program to develop and improve that organization; and that a 
program must be initiated to inform and educate water resources stakeholders and the public on 
water services and water management. Institutional structures, budgets, and changes to procedures 
to facilitate improved water sector performance should be introduced as required. The consultant 
will  prepare  monthly  progress  reports  and  a  special  report  on  procedures  for  river  basin 
management for river basin councils and local WRAs by February 2012.

12      Appendix 3 
12.  Capacity development specialist (national, 20 person-months).  The consultant should 
have a university degree in water resources engineering and at least 15 years of experience in 
water resources management projects in Indonesia. The consultant, to be located in Jakarta, 
will be responsible for assisting the team leader in assessing training needs in integrated river 
basin  management  and  institutional  strengthening  action  plans  for  integrated  river  basin 
management, and implementing capacity building activities. An early program in the capacity 
strategy needs to apply performance indicators for river basins and WRAs, which were implemented 
in river basin institutional benchmarking. The agreed performance indicators should be integrated 
with annual reporting and budget submissions by WRAs. Investments in technical hardware and 
software need to be contingent on developing appropriate funding, procedural, and staff incentive 
conditions. The consultant will develop training materials on the Water Law and regulations, the 
principles of water resources management, and the implementation of the Water Law in provincial 
and district governments. An initial 2-year phase of the capacity strategy will be implemented and, at 
the end of that period, the task force will review all programs and advise how the second phase 
should continue. The consultant will prepare monthly progress reports, a training need assessment 
report, and training materials for (i) the general and detailed provisions of the Water Law and 
regulations, (ii) the principles of water resources management, and (iii) the implementation of 
the Water Law. 
 
13.  Water  resources  planner  (two  national, 20  person-months each).  The  consultants 
should each have a university degree in water resources engineering and at least 10 years of 
experience in water resources management projects in Indonesia. The responsibility of the 
consultants, one to be located in the Aceh province and one in North Sulawesi province, will be 
to (i) act as provincial team leader, (ii) identify priority reforms in provincial water resource 
database management, (iii) guide a situation and gaps analysis of the integrated river basin 
management, (iv) review river basin frameworks and implementation plans to identify issues to 
be  addressed  by  the project,  (v)  support  water  resources  conservation activities,  and  (vi) 
evaluate  and  monitor  capacity  building  activities  on  water  resources  management.    The 
consultant will prepare monthly progress reports and a provincial water management report to 
recommend priority CDAP activities for each pilot river basin, including establishing river basin 
councils, preparing river basin strategic frameworks and implementation plans, and allocating 
the budget for improved water resources management. 
 
14.  Institution  and  finance  specialist  (two  national,  20  person-months  each).  The 
consultants should each have a university degree in water resources engineering or economics 
and at least 10 years of experience in water resources management projects in Indonesia. The 
consultants, one located in the Aceh province and one in the North Sulawesi province, need to 
have strong institutional skills, with nontechnical change management, and capacity building 
experience  to provide  complementary  skills.  The  consultants  will  train  the WRA  staff and 
stakeholders on the Water Law and regulations, and assist the provincial water resources 
department in supporting the selected provincial water resources councils. The consultants will 
support civil society stakeholders, who represent, together with private sector representatives, 
50% of the representatives under the Water Law. Capacity development programs to civil 
society organizations in the pilot river basins should ensure their full participation in the water 
resources  councils  for  nonstructural  river  basin  management.  The  consultants  will  be 
responsible for assisting the provincial water resources planner/team leader in preparing an 
institutional reform report for the provincial water resources management. The consultants will 
prepare monthly progress reports and an institutional reform report of the provincial river basin 
management in administration, financial management, and capacity building aspects.

Appendix 4  13
PILOT IMPLEMENTATION OF CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT ACTION PLAN 
 
A.  Capacity Development 
 
1.  The capacity development process has three essential phases: 
 
(i)  Performance analysis. Identify performance gaps that the organization wished to 
address. 
(ii)  Capacity diagnostic analysis. Identify the factors leading to the organizational 
gaps. 
(iii)  Strategy development. Based on the diagnostic analysis, develop strategies to 
address factors that constrain capacity. 
 
2.  The evaluations of the Asian Development Bank of a number of capacity development 
technical assistance projects indicate that such a systematic capacity development process is 
often not followed because of (i) development partners’ bias toward pre-favored interventions, 
and  (ii)  lack  of  capacity  development  capability  of  consulting  firms  working  on  capacity 
development programs. Capacity development investments will not be optimum unless a prior 
holistic, systematic, and rigorous capacity analysis, led by and involving key stakeholders in the 
organization, has already been carried out. 
 
3.  The capacity development process (strategy, pace, and sequencing) must be led by the 
organization, with help from consultants when needed. The consultant facilitator can provide a 
road  map,  help  to  avoid  barriers,  monitoring  and  feedback,  and  experience  from  lessons 
learned. Training can be cost effective and add learning to the process. Internal ownership, 
fostered from leading and participating in performance and diagnostic analysis, will lead to 
sustainability. 
 
B.  Capacity Development Action Plan 
 
4.  Capacity development action plans (CDAPs) for water resources management will help 
governments define their capacity building strategy, detailed programs, and required funding. 
The main elements of a CDAP are (i) policy framework; (ii) institutional development; (iii) human 
resource management; (iv) financial management, budgeting, and planning; (v) monitoring and 
evaluation; and (vi) human resources development, education, and training. 
 
5.  A CDAP must cover a period of implementation to deliver meaningful benefits. It was 
designed  as  a  medium-term  action  plan,  broken  down  into  annual  action  agendas  and 
investment and recurrent budgets. The process of CDAP formulation is summarized as follows: 
 
(i)  Needs assessment and diagnostic analysis. The local CDAP team maps out 
existing capacity problems and priority actions, and develops strategies in the 
main  elements  in  paragraph  4.  This  is  done  through  intensive  consultation 
between  various  state  and  non-state  agencies,  including  civil  society 
organizations. 
(ii)  Drafting of relevant components of the CDAP. This includes scheduling short- 
and medium-term measures and the provision of technical backstopping. 
(iii)  Present the draft CDAP for consultation among relevant local agencies. 
(iv)  Develop the CDAP budget through consultation between the CDAP team, the 
local financial agency, and the local parliament budgetary commission. 
(v)  The draft CDAP is reviewed by the support team at the national level.

14      Appendix 4 
 
C.  Capacity Development Action Plans under the TA for Capacity Building in Water 
Resources in a Decentralized Environment  
 
6.  Under  ADB’s  TA  for  Capacity  Building  in  Water  Resources  in  a  Decentralized 
Environment,1 the Directorate General for Water Resources prepared 29 CDAPs in December 
2009  through  (i)  project  dissemination  workshops  in  eight  provinces,  (ii)  assessment  and 
diagnostic analysis in the 41 water resources management institutions within the provinces, (iii) 
training of trainers, (iv) preparation of CDAPs, (v) a provincial workshop in each province, and 
(vi) a national workshop. This TA also prepared the guidelines for facilitating institutional self 
assessment  for  CDAP  preparation.  The  CDAP  covers  the  activities  of  policy,  institutional 
strengthening, human resources management, finance, technical water resources management, 
monitoring and evaluation, and human resources development for the river basin organization 
and provincial and district water resources agencies. 
 
7.  All  the  participating  institutions,  except  those  in  South  Kalimantan,  submitted  their 
CDAPs and had a provincial workshop with all the participating institutions in the province to 
conduct peer review of these plans. The institutions in South Kalimantan failed to submit the 
CDAPs because of their routine workload. The CDAPs showed that the number of activities for 
each  WRA  ranged  from  6  to  99  because  of  differences  in  (i)  understanding  of  change 
management  team  and  the  working  units  on the  purpose  and  role of  the  CDAP for  their 
institution; (ii) commitment of the head of the institutions; (iii) capacity of each institution to 
identify their problem, needs, and strategy; and (iv) time constraints. 
 
8.  The CDAP budget was estimated at $35.182 million for 948 activities, including national 
river basins of $8.576 million, provincial river basins of $11.230 million, and district river basins 
of $15.376 million. The two pilot provinces of Aceh and North Sulawesi were selected as 
champions for water resources management during the final workshop of the TA for Capacity 
Building  in  Water  Resources  in  a  Decentralized  Environment.  They  have  the  179  CDAP 
activities that are estimated at $12.305 million, with 55 activities in Aceh estimated at $4.839 
million for Aceh and 124 activities estimated at $7.466 million for North Sulawesi. 
 
D.  Pilot Demonstration of Capacity Development Action Plans 
 
9.  The Aceh province prepared the CDAPs for the national river basin organization of 
Sumatra 1, the provincial water resource department, the river basin organization of Aceh Besar, 
and the district government of Bireun. The North Sulawesi province prepared the CDAPs for the 
national river basin of Sulawesi 1, the provincial water resources department of North Sulawesi, 
and  the  district  government  of  Minahasa.  Those  river  basin  organizations,  provincial 
departments, and district governments will pilot demonstrate their CDAP activities.  
 
10.  Each provincial water resources department will assist in (i) establishing and facilitating 
a water resources council for each river basin, (ii) preparing a pola and a rencana for each river 
basin, and (iii) supporting training as a priority human resources development activity, which 
focuses on institution, staff, and water resources technology. The detailed CDAP implementation 
plan will be prepared during the inception workshop. The consultants will evaluate and monitor 
the capacity development activities. 
                                                
1  ADB. 2007. Technical Assistance to the Republic of Indonesia for Capacity Building in Water Resources in a 
Decentralized Environment. Manila (TA 7016-INO).
